statement.tex: \text{For the curve }y=4x^3-2x^5, \text{ find all the points}\\ \text{at which the tangent passes through the origin.}

step.context: \text{Which of the following would be}\\ \text{true of the required tangents?}
step.reason: \text{If the tangents pass through the origin,}\\ \text{then they must satisfy }\frac{y-0}{x-0}=m.\text{ And, what}\\ \text{is }m=?.\text{ It is the slope of the tangent} = \frac{dy}{dx}.

step.tex: \begin{align} \dfrac{y}{x}&= \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{d}{dx}(4x^3-2x^5)\\ &= 12x^2-10x^4 \\ \implies \dfrac{4x^3-2x^5}{x}&= 12x^2 - 10x^4 \\ \implies 4x^3-2x^5 &= 12x^3 - 10x^5\\ \implies 8x^3\cdot(x^2-1) &= 0 \text{ or }x=0,\pm 1 \end{align} \\ \text{The required points, therefore, are}\\ \begin{tabular}{ccc} x& y=4x^3-2x^5&(x,y) \\ \hline 0&0 &(0,0)\\ 1&2&(1,2)\\ -1&-2&(-1,-2)\\ \hline \end{tabular}

\begin{align} \dfrac{y}{x}&= \dfrac{dy}{dx} = \dfrac{d}{dx}(4x^3-2x^5)\\ &= 12x^2-10x^4 \\ \implies \dfrac{4x^3-2x^5}{x}&= 12x^2 - 10x^4 \\ \implies\dfrac{2x^3\cdot(2-x^2)}{x}&= 2x^2\cdot(6-5x^2) \\ \implies 2-x^2&= 6-5x^2\text{ or }4x^2 = 4 \\ \implies x^2 &= 1\text{ or }x=\pm 1 \end{align} \\ \text{The required points, therefore, are}\\ \begin{tabular}{ccc} x& y=4x^3-2x^5&(x,y) \\ \hline 1&2&(1,2)\\ -1&-2&(-1,-2)\\ \hline \end{tabular}
step.reason: \text{Did you do the following?}\\ \frac{4x^3-2x^5}{x}=\frac{2x^3\cdot(2-x^2)}{x} = 2x^2\cdot(2-x^2)\\ \text{If yes, then know that, }\frac{x^n}{x}=x^{n-1}\text{ only if }x\neq 0.\\ \text{Division by zero is not defined.}
